file_name: Indonesia_Floods and volcanic activity in Indonesia-Week 20 2024
summary: Indonesia is currently experiencing multiple natural disasters, primarily severe flash floods and cold lava flows from Mount Marapi in West Sumatra, which began on May 11[12]. The death toll from these events has risen to 67, with 20 people still missing, and earlier reports indicated 57 victims found dead and 22 missing[23]. These disasters have affected at least six regencies and cities, including Agam and Tanah Datar, destroying hundreds of homes and damaging public infrastructure[7]. President Joko Widodo has directed authorities to accelerate the rebuilding of damaged infrastructure, while rescue operations involve thermal drones, excavators, and manual searching for survivors[21]. Weather modification technology is being deployed to reduce rainfall intensity, and a state of emergency is in effect until May 26[11]. Concurrently, Mount Ibu in North Maluku Province has seen a series of eruptions since April, with a significant eruption on May 27 spewing ash 6km high, prompting the evacuation of residents from seven nearby villages and over 12,000 people from a nearby island[20][21][22]. The volcano's alert level has been elevated to IV, and aviation warnings have been issued[21]. Additionally, earlier in May, flooding in Ogan Komering Ulu, South Sumatra, affected 1,695 families and displaced 257, causing substantial material losses[24].

11.context: AntaraIggoy el FitraP resident Joko "Jokowi" Widodo has instructed authorities to work faster to rebuild damaged public infrastructure in West Sumatra following flash floods and lahars earlier this month that killed dozens of people and destroyed hundreds of homes in at least six regencies and cities in the province.On Tuesday morning, Jokowi visited Agam regency, one of areas hit hardest by the series of disasters, which began on May 11. "Most roads and temporary bridges have been rebuilt, although there are one or two that are still under construction. This is what we are pushing so that everything returns to normal soon," he said, as quoted in a Presidential Secretariat press release.Dozens of people in Agam are still taking shelter, while authorities are clearing debris and repairing damaged infrastructure. questions_and_answers.question: How is the ongoing volcanic activity of Mount Ibu being communicated to the public and relevant stakeholders to ensure safety and preparedness?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer: The ongoing volcanic activity of Mount Ibu is being communicated through several channels to ensure safety and preparedness. The Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (PVMBG) has elevated the status of Ibu Volcano Alert Level to Alert Level IV[21]. The country's volcanology agency has also issued a warning for aviation authorities managing local flights[25]. Authorities have communicated the need for evacuation, leading to the evacuation of people from seven nearby villages[22][25][26]and more than 12,000 people on a nearby island[22][25][26]. Additionally, BPBD Halmahera Barat is on-site and has implemented an emergency alert status, Siaga Darurat[21]. The PVMBG has also released handout photos showing Mount Ibu spewing thick smoke[23][24].

questions_and_answers.question: What measures have been taken to extend the danger zone westward from the summit of Mount Marapi, and how has this impacted the village of Amakaka?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer: The danger zone has been extended westward by 3 kilometers from the summit of Mount Marapi[1]. This decision was made because the lava flow is moving toward Amakaka from the western area[1]. The lava flow has reached a distance of 1,200 meters from the summit or 2,800 meters from the village of Amakaka[1]. This extension is impacting the village of Amakaka[1].

1.context: Previously, the danger zone was limited to the southeastern region affecting villages such as Todanara, Jontona, Lamawolo, Lamatokan, Baolaliduli, and Lamaau. However, it has now been extended westward by 3 kilometers from the summit, impacting the village of Amakaka. This decision was made due to the lava flow moving toward Amakaka from the western area, which has already reached a distance of 1,200 meters from the summit or 2,800 meters from the village of AmakakaLocation:Kec.

questions_and_answers.question: How many people have been killed and evacuated due to the flash floods and cold lava flow in West Sumatra, and what is the status of the missing persons?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer:
The death toll from the flash floods and cold lava flow in West Sumatra has risen to 67 as of Thursday[34]. Earlier reports indicated 43 deaths on May 11[40], 44 by May 13[40], 50 by May 14[37], 52 by Tuesday[32], 57 by May 14[36], 58 by Wednesday[34], and 62 by Wednesday[34].

Approximately 3,200 people are temporarily displaced to safer areas[31], and more than 3,000 people were evacuated[40].

As of Thursday, 20 people are still missing[34]. Previously, 25 people were missing, with five of them later found dead[34]. Search and rescue operations are ongoing for the missing people[36][37], with local rescuers, police, and military personnel involved[38].

Impact assessments are ongoing, with over 350 houses and other buildings reported heavily damaged. Local government agencies, in collaboration with the Indonesian Red Cross and other responders, have provided food, non-food items, hygiene kits, shelter materials, and clean water to affected people.Between 9-12 May, floods up to one meter high were reported in South Aceh District in Aceh Province and North Konawe District in Southeast Sulawesi.

questions_and_answers.question: What specific actions are being taken by the Pacific Disaster Center (PDC) and the ASEAN Coordinating Centre for Humanitarian Assistance on Disaster Management (AHA Centre) to enhance disaster risk reduction in Indonesia?
questions_and_answers.updated_retrieved_answer: The Pacific Disaster Center (PDC) and the ASEAN Coordinating Centre for Humanitarian Assistance on Disaster Management (AHA Centre) are enhancing disaster risk reduction and humanitarian assistance throughout the ASEAN region[1]. Their collaboration includes the launch and continuous enhancement of the Disaster Monitoring and Response System (DMRS)[1]. DMRS provides near-real-time impact analysis, advanced analytics, insights, and actionable information for a multitude of hazards[1], serving all ASEAN Member States[1]. The AHA Centre also provides early warning and impact analysis through DMRS, as well as training and capacity development for ASEAN Member States[2]. Additionally, PDC and the AHA Centre have collaborated on disaster risk assessments and exercise engagements, including ARDEX, ADMM-Plus, and national-level exercises[2].

1.context: title: Pacific Disaster Center and the AHA Centre reaffirm their shared dedication to disaster risk reduction  content: By: Chani GoeringJakarta, IndonesiaThe Pacific Disaster Center PDC and the ASEAN Coordinating Centre for Humanitarian Assistance on Disaster Management AHA Centre recently announced the renewal of their long-held partnership through a new Memorandum of Intent MOI to enhance disaster risk reduction and humanitarian assistance throughout the ASEAN region. "We are honored to continue our successful and longstanding partnership with the AHA Centre. Our work with ASEAN spans more than two decades and we've celebrated numerous successes with the AHA Centre since it was first initiated as a regional hub for disaster risk reduction nearly fifteen years ago.Through our collaboration with experts at the AHA Centre, the first regional multi-hazard early warning and risk intelligence platform known as the Disaster Monitoring and Response System, or DMRS, was launched in 2012 to serve all ASEAN Member States. Today, DMRS provides near-real-time impact analysis advanced analytics, insights, and actionable information, for a multitude of hazards, empowering decision-makers to understand risks and quickly mobilize life-saving humanitarian resources.
1.title: Pacific Disaster Center and the AHA Centre reaffirm their shared dedication to disaster risk reduction

2.context: "PDC Executive Director Ray ShirkhodaiDMRS is powered by PDC's DisasterAWARE technology and was launched as a collaborative effort between PDC and the AHA Centre in 2012. PDC and the AHA Centre have since collaborated on disaster risk assessments and exercise engagements over the years, including ARDEX, ADMM-Plus, and national-level exercises and have continuously enhanced DMRS to bolster the readiness and resilience of Member States. "The AHA Centre is mandated to facilitate the coordination of disaster management among ASEAN Member States, providing early warning and impact analysis through DMRS, as well as training and capacity development. The work we've done with PDC over the years to enhance DMRS, as well as their expertise in risk assessment and predictive analytics has been integral to our operations and to the overall disaster risk reduction objectives of the region."
2.title: Pacific Disaster Center and the AHA Centre reaffirm their shared dedication to disaster risk reduction
